want to develop the land around the week
and a half ago the villagers all ran out

this morning one of the leaders of the

came back from the meeting sounding
somewhat optimistic saying that

in the afternoon mr. Lin the

like the American people are having to
do the payroll tax cut was originally
part of the stimulus bill or a version

the end of last year and now it's due to
expire again and so this big fight you
see in Congress is whether to extend it
for 2012 if it's not extended taxes will
go up on on most households it's an
average of just under a thousand dollars
per worker for about a hundred and sixty
million workers out there that's one of
the reasons that economists are really
quite nervous about this some even say
it could send the economy into recession
again I think most don't think that most
think it will significantly slowed
growth and slow hiring next year if it
expires mr. Bennett so the question then
is why do we see this stalemate and we
see the stalemate because the two
parties really are at fundamental
loggerheads over all kinds of things the
Democrats are overwhelmingly want to
extend this tax cut the amendment is
agreed to congressional Republicans are
more divided some of them want to extend
it and you saw a lot of Republican votes
in the Senate for extending it but
particularly a lot of people in the
house do not and there are really two
things going on here some are skeptical
of the effect of temporary tax cuts the
idea of driba and driving little bits of
money each year they say the thing that
stimulates the economy is permanent tax
cuts the other issue though is what they
would get in return for extending this
payroll tax cut if this were simply an
up-or-down vote on the payroll tax cut I
think it could pass relatively easily
the question is what price can
Republicans exact from Democrats for
extending it a lot of the focus is now
has been on this pipeline
whether Democrats will agree to this
pipeline running through the middle of
the country and I think when you put
this together you understand why
expectations are so low for Congress
getting anything done in 2012 there are
these basic disagreements we are
probably not going to see them resolved
until the American people weigh in again
and kind of break the tie of the 2008

perhaps gets more control than either
one has right now how'd the browser
and Steven Spielberg's movie The

it's based on a series of comic books

they're books about a character i'm
going to snobbishly call tan-tan because
that is how he would call himself he was
the creation of a Belgian cartoonist
named George Raimi who went by the pen
name RJ that Spielberg would choose

sudden switches and transitions and
they're meticulously drawn
on the other hand the movie doesn't look
very much like the tan tan books maybe
that's inevitable maybe it's part of

performing that magic trick of making
the pictures seem to move just a thing
to me is to see one if the movie catches
